_decoded_content.title: Hub metadata for plugins should be a superset of necessary fields in `discovery.yml`
_decoded_content.description:
As a path to unblock https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/3031+ and also to replace `discovery.yml` in the Meltano project with the metadata here in the Hub, we'd like to ensure that Hub metadata is a superset of the needed data that is currently present in `meltano.yml`.

## Important exceptions and deprecations

| Setting | Description | Resolution or Mitigation
| ------ | ------ | ------ |
| `settings.env` | A method of either _injecting_ or _sourcing_ environment variables | We support for non-singer plugins. We remove those references used for "sourcing". We remove injection scenarios for Singer plugins unless required (logging an issue with the dev requesting them to support a `settings.json` - based config). We may also consider a rename to something like `as_env_var` or `mapped_env_var` so this is more specifically targeted to _injecting_ env vars rather than its current dual role of injecting and/or sourcing. | 
| `settings.env_aliases` | Same as `env` but allowing multiple inputs and outputs. | Deprecate this. No support. |
| `settings.select` | Used to create default select patterns for a given tap. | Deprecate. This was primarily needed for transform packages (also deprecated) which had specific table and field requirements. |
| `settings.metadata` | Used similarly to `select` as a means of overriding selection defaults. | Deprecate, same as `select` metadata. |
| `settings.aliases` | Alternative names that can be used in `meltano.yml` and with `meltano config set`. | Keep as-is and provide a list of common/standard aliases to support interop across forks and utilities: e.g. `password`, `user`, `database_name`, `schema_name`, etc. |
| `settings.value` | The default value if no other value is provided. | Keep, but perhaps rename to `default` to make the function of this more clear. |
| `settings.placeholder` | Used to hint to the user what kind of entry is supported | Keep (as optional). |
| `settings.description` | Optional. Used to provide inline context. | Keep. |
| `settings.tooltip` | Optional. Used to provide additional inline context. | Keep. Or remove and merge with `description`. |
| `settings.documentation` | Optional. Used to provide inline context. | Deprecate and merge into `description`. |
| `settings.value_processor` | Modify value before loading it from source. | Deprecate. | 
| `settings.value_post_processor` | Modify value after loading it from source. | Deprecate. |
| `settings.protected` | Use in combination with `value` to provide an uneditable default. | Deprecate. |

## Move to a single yaml format in the hub per plugin

Currently we have two yaml files per (discoverable) plugin. This would move us to one-yaml-per-plugin and would allow us to fully deprecate `discovery.yml` after a certain amount of time has passed.


## Alignment of Settings `kind`

As discussed in #25+, our settings types need to be converted or aligned between Meltano and the hub.

A possible path forward:

1. Decide in #25 what the new settings types/kinds will be, probably including a separate "sensitive" boolean flag per setting.
2. Add support for those new settings types in Meltano.
3. Deprecate, but do not entirely drop support for the old settings types. (Essentially, those would be aliases until we fully remove them.)
4. Consider deprecating the older style in Meltano in a `2.0` release.

_decoded_content.title: Clarify in docs what a setting is vs what a config is
_decoded_content.description:
From https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/3211 and private Slack thread https://meltano.slack.com/archives/C02MBDUHCCD/p1643827549868919:

>>> 
Settings are specified as part of plugin definitions for the purposes of discovery. Config is the mechanism by which the fields described as settings are populated with values.

Whilst `settings` usually only appear in `discovery.yml`, custom plugins added in `meltano.yml` places `settings` and `config` in the same view.
>>>

_decoded_content.title: Discovery.yml Discussion
_decoded_content.description:
@aaronsteers and I had a conversation about the long term plan for discovery.yml so this issue is to document my understand.

Sources of truth:
- Transformers/Utilities/Files/etc. = meltano repo. They will be split out into individual files for easier maintenance.
- Tap/Target definitions = hub repo. There should be no difference between taps/targets and extractors/loaders - currently the env_alias is the only known customization which is a legacy feature now that all settings can be managed in environment variables using `TAP_GITLAB_X` syntax.

The ideal implementation in my mind is to still have a discovery.yml as part of Meltano but make it automatically generated vs a static versioned file. The goal is to allow stability for teams that want it but also have the most up to date settings by default (using the hub as a singer definition API). By keeping the discovery.yml and the current logic we still allow teams to pin their version for stability. By introducing logic to dynamically generate discovery.yml we can give users the most up to date settings by default based on MeltanoHub whenever without a release or version bump needed.

How it would work:
1. MRs to MeltanoHub to get settings updated for Singer plugins. MRs to Meltano for other plugins.
1. The current versioned discovery.yml is removed from the git repo. And tests are updated to point to  https://www.meltano.com/discovery.yml instead. The [plugin_discovery_service logic](https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/blob/master/src/meltano/core/plugin_discovery_service.py#L98) is updated to generate discovery.yml as the second step if no pinned version found, meaning retrieve discovery.yml in this order: project pinned, generate a new one using MeltanoHub API latest singer definitions along with the discovery [endpoint](https://www.meltano.com/discovery.yml) for other plugins (only parsing out non-singer plugins), plain discovery [endpoint](https://www.meltano.com/discovery.yml), `/cache/` directory, or finally the build artifact in `meltano.core.bundle` (see next step).
1. On Meltano releases CI dynamically generates a discovery.yml and places it in the bundle directory as a build artifact. The challenge here is that the hub can be changing all the time and if the timing is bad and the hub had a mistake in settings at the time we created a meltano release then we are packaging a bad file with the release. Its probably a fine risk since generating it at runtime is the preferred workflow (see above) which would fix it or for people who really need stability theyll have it pinned so it wont matter.
1. MeltanoHub tap/target endpoints are versioned on every release to main so [this endpoint](https://hub.meltano.com/singer/api/v1/taps.json) can serve every version the users might want. We make a V2 endpoint that includes the version (UPDATE: a [separate issue](https://gitlab.com/meltano/hub/-/issues/180) for the versioned singer metadata endpoint has since been opened) 

This endpoint currently https://hub.meltano.com/singer/api/v1/taps.json, and returns:
```
[
    {
        "singer_name": "tap-csv",
        ...
        "variants": [{},...]
    }
]
```

The new endpoint has the version in the URI like https://hub.meltano.com/singer/api/v2/123/taps.json, and returns:
```
{
    "version": 123,
    "taps": [
        {
            "singer_name": "tap-csv",
            ...
            "variants": [{},...]
        }
    ]
}
```
I'm open to implementing it differently but the idea is that users always know what version of settings theyre running. For troubleshooting well want to know if they have the latest settings definition or at what version an issue was introduced.

Not immediately necessary but we might also want a mechanism for generating a discovery using a specific singer_definition version. Maybe `meltano discovery_pin --singer_def_version 123` since on the fly generation always uses the latest version.


Ordered steps to get there:
1. Remove discovery.yml from git, generate as a build artifact, and fix tests to point to the endpoint. Just read split out files for now. https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/merge_requests/2456#note_761359255 does most of this already.
1. MeltanoHub singer_definition versioned endpoint
1. Update the discovery generator logic to pull from the new singer_definitions endpoint, remove all split out files from the meltano repo, update [plugin discovery service](https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/blob/master/src/meltano/core/plugin_discovery_service.py#L98) to run generation code after not finding a pinned version.
1. `meltano discovery_pin --singer_def_version 123` CLI command?


@tayloramurphy @aaronsteers What do you guys think about this?


Future Future:
- I think this would be a lot more work but we could eventually just use the hub as an endpoint without generating a discovery.yml unless the user asks for it (aka `meltano discovery_pin` (or something). This would require a more sophisticated hub API to allow tap/target filtering etc. and meltano a tighter integration with MeltanoHub logic to not always look at the discovery.yml but rather just make API requests instead. This goes a bit in the opposite direction of decoupling from Singer more though.

_decoded_content.title: Shorten CI Runtime by Limiting Tests Based on Which Files Change
_decoded_content.description:
Currently a change to a discovery.yml runs CI tests that take ~1 hr. See [target-bigquery](https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/pipelines/422245494) change.

We should be able to run a subset of these tests to encourage faster iteration on discoverable plugins.

_decoded_content.title: Add lock artifacts during `meltano add` for stability and portability of plugin definitions
_decoded_content.description:
This has come up twice this week, especially in context of pipelines and integrations with external tools.

## Original proposal

Original proposal recommends an actual `.lock.yml` file.

<details><summary>Click to expand</summary>

1. `meltano lock` would generate or update a lock file - also in yaml format.
2. This would resolve all dependencies, including the `discovery.yml` ref and combination of all `include-path` files for multi-meltano files.

In future iterations this could be expanded to:

3. Include `catalog.json` caches.
4. Resolve all config representations of `environments` so that each environment has a fully resolved schema (_except_ secrets and the content of any externally-managed environment variables.)~~ - Not needed in initial release.
5. Optionally, include rich information of the DAG structure for known/declared pipelines or schedules.

Based on this lock file artifact, external tools such as Terraform, Databand, etc. could build environments and/or obtain rich project metadata needed for integration.

This may also provide improved stability projects for projects running in the wild, as discussed in this comment: https://gitlab.com/groups/meltano/-/epics/128#note_734475476

</details>

### Alternate implementation option (2022-02-10)

Here's an alternative that just focuses on freezing the plugin definitions, ideally copying those verbatim from their source of truth on hub.meltano.com

#### Stable Installations via `meltano add`

We alter how `meltano add` installs new plugins:

1. Instead of installing directly from `discovery.yml` and relying on the `discovery.yml` definition for resolution, we go to https://hub.meltano.com and download the file associated with the plugin.
2. The downloaded definition file will be installed into `${MELTANO_PROJECT_DIR}/plugins/` as `${MELTANO_PROJECT_DIR}/plugins/extractors/tap-mytap--variantname.yml`.
3. An optional `plugin_definitions_path: <str>` config option in `meltano.yml` will allow users to change the default path. This would simply default to `${MELTANO_PROJECT_DIR}/plugins` if not set by the user.
    - This is separate from [include_paths](https://docs.meltano.com/concepts/project#multiple-yaml-files) in `meltano.yml`, since (1) we need to know exactly where to download new definitions and (2) the plugin definition files adhere to a new plugin spec format and not to the `meltano.yml` project format.
4. After downloading the definition, the plugin entry will be added to `meltano.yml` exactly as is performed today.
5. Instead of resolving setting definitions via `discovery.yml`, `meltano.yml` will only refer to the downloaded definitions.
    - This will require a one-time update to our parser to also interpret and import data from the native/standard plugin definitions from hub.meltano.com.

#### Definition updates via `meltano add --upgrade`

We add something like `meltano add extractor tap-mytap --upgrade` which will replace the current definition with the new definition.

#### Migration to locked definitions via `meltano install --lock` or `meltano install --freeze`

For projects already in the wild, we can add a `--lock` or `--freeze` option to `meltano install` which generates a "locked" plugin definition file for any which are missing. As above, this would create one file per plugin used in the project. If a plugin definition already exists, we skip adding that file.

#### "Single-file option"

I think we've declined this option so I'm collapsing it. Please sound off in comments if you have a strong preference otherwise.

<details><summary>Click to expand</summary>

~~As an alternative to downloading and adding files individually, we could follow basically the same behavior as described, except we import/merge definitions in a single file called something at the root of the Meltano project dir like `plugins-registry.yml`, `registered-plugins.yml`, or `plugins-definitions.yml`. Since it would be a single file, we could have it at a fixed path relative to the root, and perhaps in the future allow the user to specify their own path to that file.

(AJ Speaking) I'm personally less inclined towards the single-lock file approach after thinking on this more. The one-file-per-plugin approach creates cleaner file diffs and is more scalable for a large number of plugins.~~

</details>

#### Deprecating `discovery.yml`

After implementing this proposal, `discovery.yml` as it exists today would be fully deprecated. Projects which have not yet had their definitions locked would still fall back to the bundled `discovery.yml` file. For the purposes of not breaking users on older versions, we would simply leave the online version of this file (https://discovery.meltano.com/discovery.yml) frozen at a point in time without needing to continue maintaining updates in `discovery.yml`.

#### Spec versioning

As @aphethean calls out in a thread on this issue https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/3031#note_842196683, we also need to handle spec versioning so that the file spec can evolve without breaking users.

For instance, @aphethean provides a sample used by Kubernetes (`apiVersion: networking.k8s.io/v1beta1`) and we can see something similar in `dbt`'s use of `config-version: 2`.

This makes sure we meet this requirement as expressed in the comment:

> 1. ‘meltano add extractor tap-csv’
> 1. Aeons later, tap-csv plugin definition will always work with my meltano project.

_decoded_content.title: Add `includes` to individual Meltano yaml files to ref clean Singer yaml
_decoded_content.description:
For each tap and target we will create a syntax that references the clean Singer yaml spec for every tap and target. On the YAML we'll have the overrides / additions for each setting and other Meltano-specific items that discovery.yml cares about.

---

As the spec is defined for Singer Taps and Targets for the Hub and for the SDK, we'll have to translate from those specs into what's required and useful for Meltano. 

For example, one of the key things we document in target-bigquery is how the load_schema is set based on their configuration in the extractor. https://meltano.com/plugins/loaders/bigquery.html#dataset-id That information shouldn't be on the Hub, but it will need to be synced with the hub to work well with Meltano.

2021-05-04 - We're bumping this up in priority to make the sync the clean yaml spec in the hub easier for Meltano. We'll have an `includes:` syntax and then Meltano-specific things to make the sync easier.

_decoded_content.title: Push split discovery.yml files to the Hub
_decoded_content.description:
Once the files are split, we should have a push step on any release to update the files on the Hub. 

Alternatively we _could_ have the Hub fetch the latest files everytime we're built. Open to that as as an option as well.

_decoded_content.title: Switch from single discovery.yml file to generated one
_decoded_content.description: Following from https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/3010, switch to using the generated file.

_decoded_content.title: Generate discovery.yml from individual files
_decoded_content.description:
As proposed in https://gitlab.com/meltano/hub/-/issues/120 it would be valuable to have discovery.yml broken up into separate files similar to what's been done in the Hub https://gitlab.com/meltano/hub/-/tree/main/_data/meltano

This issue should track splitting the file up and generating / validating it matches the current full discovery.yml file.

_decoded_content.title: Docs: Update discovery.yml documentation to indicate  versioning and assumptions
_decoded_content.description:
Based on all the updates we want to make in meltano&128 the documentation such as `https://www.meltano.com/docs/contributor-guide.html#discovery-yml-version` should be updated to reflect reality.

New assumptions are mostly documented in https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2992#note_708547645 but basically we'd never remove a variant (or a plugin probably) and rely on #3005 to indicate deprecated status.

_decoded_content.title: Create a JSON Schema for discovery.yml
_decoded_content.description: Perhaps we want a JSON schema for each plugin type

_decoded_content.title: Add a deprecated indication to plugins
_decoded_content.description:
From https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2992 we've identified that `hidden: true` only hides a connector from the UI. 

We should add a `deprecated` boolean flag and optionally a `deprecation_warning` string field for all plugins and extractor/loader variants. 

Alternative would be:

```yaml
deprecated:
  status: true #default is fales
  warning: "This was removed 2021-10-11 and replaced with X" # This would be optional and would have a sane default.
```

I like the idea of keeping `hidden` as it currently is. For connectors that we want to deprecate, we could take a staged process to remove it from the UI via `hidden` and then fully deprecate in a subsequent release.

_decoded_content.title: Use a versioned discovery.yml endpoint
_decoded_content.description:
As discussed here: https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2992#note_708547645

This would create version-specific http endpoints for `discovery.yml`. We may also want to host an endpoint for one or more "prerelease" versions.

_decoded_content.title: Improve user experience around caching and fetching discovery.yml
_decoded_content.description:
This issue is to discuss mitigating problems documented in https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2993

From https://gitlab.com/meltano/sdk/-/issues/244#note_707960285 we probably need a versioning scheme for discovery.yml itself with the option / ability to fetch the latest "unreleased" version. Better messages on the command line and UI indicating what's happening and whether there's a mismatch or not is essential. Perhaps if it's versioned we could even automatically fetch old versions to see if that resolves an error?

Clarifying for the user in the documentation as well about how discovery.yml is cached and fetched would be good. 

@aaronsteers @pnadolny13

_decoded_content.title: Re-evaluate Meltano files in Hub
_decoded_content.description:
After a discussion with AJ, we realized that storing the Meltano-specific files in the Hub is going to create more problems than it solves. 

Because only the extractors and loaders are currently the only plugins tied to an underlying standard ecosystem (Singer), it doesn't make sense to have all of the other Meltano-specific plugins defined in Hub, particularly when it's just for use in discovery.yml.

It seems like the better solution would be to move the individual files back to the meltano project, generate the discovery.yml there, and then as we standardize the clean Singer YAML files the files stored in Meltano can be updated to reference the Singer files. 

Steps:
* Move files from Hub to Meltano
* Generate discovery.yml in Meltano from separate files
* Add validation check for existing vs generated one
* Switch to using generated one
* Incrementally switch Meltano files to referencing clean Singer files

_decoded_content.title: Standardize setting types including sensitive and other properties
_decoded_content.description:
Specifically around `kind: password`, this should be refactored into something like:

```yaml
- name: pg_password
  kind: string
  sensitive: true
```
